## Current Account Basics

[Definition:]{.hp} 
Records the transaction of goods, services, investment income, and unilateral transfers between residents of a country and the rest of the world

<br>

::: {.fragment}
- Exports & Imports

- Income on Equities

- Income on Debt-related Assests

- Repatriated Income by Multinational Enterprise (MNE) firms
:::

---

## Current Account Inflows

<br>

Current Account Inflows are [monetary inflows]{.hp}, exchanged for [goods/services outflows]{.hp}

<br>

Country [current account surplus]{.hp} implies [CA Inflows]{.hp} are greater than [CA Outflows]{.hp}

<br>

::: {.fragment .align-center}
$\Rightarrow$ Outflow of goods, services, investment income, etc. of country are greater than inflows
:::

---

## Capital & Financial Accounts

[Capital Account:]{.hp}

::: {.fragment}
Records transactions of highly specialized financial assets and liabilities
:::

::: {.fragment}
- Gifts of an embassy
- Acquisition of land for embassy use
:::

[Financial Account:]{.hp}

::: {.fragment}
Tracks capital flows between economies, usually long-lasting items relative to goods or services
:::

::: {.fragment}
- Foreign Investment
- Purchase or sales of foreign stock & bonds
- International bank lending
:::

---

## CA: Trade Balance

The [trade balance]{.hp} is total exports minus total imports

::: {.incremental}
- A [trade balance deficit]{.hi} is a case in which total imports of goods and services outweighs total exports
- It is possible to maintain a deficit in goods and surplus in srevices, but normally the net amount of both is considered 
:::

::: {.fragment}
For the US, the 2023 USD trade balance was [$3,053.5 bn]{.h} minus [$3,8269 bn]{.h}, or [$951.2 bn]{.h}.

Because the [value is negative]{.hp}, the United States had a [trade deficit]{.hp}
:::

---

## CA: Breakdown

[Current Account]{.hp} measures all current, non-financial transactions between a nation and the rest of the world

::: {.incremental}
- Goods and Services trade [(Trade Balance)]{.hp}

- Earned income paid abroad and received from abroad [(Primary Income)]{.hp}

- International transfer payments [(Secondary Income)]{.hp}
:::

::: {.fragment}
All three of these items have [credit and debit]{.h} components in BoP and in the construction of [CA balance]{.h}
:::

## CA: Primary Income

Useful to think of [primary income]{.hp} as payments or receipts for use of financial capital

::: {.fragment .small}
> If a US company invests in Mexico's stock market, the initial investment will not show up in the current account but will be included in the financial account. 
:::

::: {.fragment .small}
> Subsequent flow of dividends back to the US company will be counted in the United States as [income received]{.h} and in Mexico as [income paid]{.h}. 
:::

::: {.fragment .small}
> If US company operating in Mexico pays wages from its home in the US, the wages are included in the primary income category of the current account and are recorded as a receipt by Mexico and payment by the US.
:::

---

## CA: Secondary Income

[Secondary Income]{.hp} includes payments made that are not in exchange for a good or service

::: {.fragment}
- [Foreign aid]{.hp}, or the [remittances]{.hp} (transfer of wages earned in one country to residents of another country) of immigrants temporarily residing in another country
:::

<br>

::: {.fragment}
In US, payments are small relative to the overall current account

Transfers are sometimes [very important]{.hi} to developing countries receiving large volumes of either foreign aid or remittances from their citizens working abroad 
:::

## CA: US Case

<br>

The US [current account deficit]{.hp} has been trending downards for the past 50 years

<br>

We will explore the causes and consequences of large current account deficits later, but here it should be noted that [a current account deficit is not simply a sign of weakness]{.h}

<br>

::: {.fragment}
Rapid economic growth in US [raised income]{.hp}, increased spending power means greater imports
:::

---

## CA: US Case

<br>

Foreign incomes did not rise as rapidly

<br>

::: {.fragment}
Current account deficit in 1990s was a sign of [relative US economic strength]{.hp}
:::

<br>

::: {.fragment}
Deficit is not sustainable in the long-run and could create [serious future problems]{.hp}
:::
